section.title: General
section.para: The first edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff was produced in 1958 (ref). This publication arose from representations by the Local Government and Highways Engineering Branch of the Sydney Division of the Institution of Engineers, Australia which ultimately led to the formation of Technical Committee No. 2 - Stormwater Standards. The terms of reference of this committee are outlined in full by ref but can be summarised as to investigate rainfall intensities as well as the standard of practice in assessing discharge from catchment areas, frequency of flooding to be adopted in design and allied drainage problems.

The Technical Committee ultimately evolved into the Institution of Engineers, Australia’s National Committee on Hydrology who in 1972 recognised that there was a need to revise Australian Rainfall and Runoff. This revision was published in 1977 as the second edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff (ref). In the preparation of this edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff it was recognised that the purpose of the previous edition was to provide an unofficial code of recommended practice in the selection and application of approaches to hydrologic problems. In the preparation of the second edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, therefore, an attempt was made to remove the code of practice concept from the contents and to include in the document information about Australian rainfall characteristics and a description of some methods of hydrologic analysis and constraints which apply to their use. As such, the second edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff was intended to be a handbook of information and hydrologic method. It was stated in the preface to this edition that the National Committee saw the need for the engineering hydrologists to be perceptive about problems and to develop solutions for these problems in a way that was most appropriate to the location, situation, information and skills that were available.

In 1982, the National Committee on Hydrology and Water Resources of the Institution of Engineers, Australia recognised the need to revise the second edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff. This revised edition was published in 1987 (Pilgrim, 1987). In commissioning the 1987 edition, the National Committee on Hydrology and Water Resources of the Institution of Engineers, Australia adopted the view that much firmer guidance should be given to designers. It was considered that the profession required a guide to practice that can be regarded as authoritative by all stakeholders. It was recognised also that irrespective of the attitude taken by an editorial committee or the National Committee on Hydrology and Water Resources, a document published by the Institution of Engineers, Australia will inevitably be regarded as a statement of sound and desirable practice. For these reasons, the third edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff provided firmer guidance on appropriate methodologies for analysis of hydrologic problems and the design of hydrologic structures. Furthermore, in previous editions of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, information pertaining to the rainfall characteristics had been limited to points where data were available. In this edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, information about rainfall characteristics across the complete country was attempted and, as a result, the third edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff was published in two volumes for the first time. The intention of splitting Australian Rainfall and Runoff into two volumes was that the first edition would contain the guidance while the second volume would contain information that was necessary for implementation of the recommended approaches but which was not necessary for presentation of the approach.

In 1997, the 3rd Edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff was republished with the Chapters in Volume 1 rearranged into eight books. No changes were made to Volume 2 of the document. Following this republication, Book 6 - Extreme and Large Floods was completely revised and a new version published in 1999. No other books or chapters were revised and therefore the 3rd Edition, published in 1987, remained current.

This edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff is the fourth edition. Following the re-publication of the 3rd Edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, it was recognised by Engineers Australia’s National Committee on Water Engineering that the increased computational capacity available to engineering and related professions was resulting in significant changes in the approaches being used for flood estimation within Australia. Additionally, theoretical advances in flood estimation techniques and their understanding had resulted in the approaches to design flood estimation presented in the 3rd Edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff no longer representing best practice. Furthermore, there has been a recognition that the information needs from design flood estimates had expanded. An example of this expansion of information needs is the common requirement now for pluvial design flood estimates in urban areas; pluvial floods are those arising from surface runoff that is flowing towards a drainage channel (surface or underground). The techniques presented in the 3rd Edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff were focussed on fluvial design flood estimates (i.e. focussed on estimating floods that arise as a result of overflows from drainage channels) and many are not suitable for development of a pluvial design flood estimate (see, for example, ref needed).

As a result of this recognition for the revision of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, the National Committee on Water Engineering commenced work in 2003 on the preparation of a revision to Australian Rainfall and Runoff. Preparation of this 4th Edition has been supported significantly by the Commonwealth of Australia through grants from the Department of Climate Change and Energy Efficiency, and Geosciences Australia, and by the profession through the in-kind support provided by many private companies, state and local government agencies, and universities.

Similar to the previous editions of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, it was recognised that, irrespective of the attitude taken by the editorial committee or the National Committee on Water Engineering, a document published by the Engineers Australia will inevitably be regarded as a statement of sound and desirable practice. For this reason, the editorial committee decided that all methodologies presented in the document needed to meet the following:

listitem.para: Methods to be included had to be published and subjected to peer review by the profession;
Methods to be included had to be based on real data; and

Methods to be included needed to be capable of design flood estimation for potential future climate regimes where suitable information is available or is expected to become available in the foreseeable future.

section.para: In addition, the editorial committee recognised that

listitem.para: Generation of new information and new technologies was likely to increase and, therefore, the information in the new edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff needed to be capable of easy change when necessary;
Design flood predictions are not exact and hence the uncertainty in prediction needed to be conveyed to users;

Information and methodologies are becoming increasingly digital in nature and that it was incumbent on Australian Rainfall and Runoff to provide software for situations where market economics has resulted in a failure to provide suitable software; and

It was not the role of Australian Rainfall and Runoff to endorse particular software packages but rather to endorse design flood estimation methodologies which can be, or have been, incorporated into software for use by the industry.
